item.name: Promethean Fire
entries: The Promethean fire stands as a symbol of enlightenment, marking the dawn of human civilization. This sacred flame, stolen from the gods by Prometheus, embodies the spirit of innovation and resilience. Contained within a magical vessel, the fire's eternal glow represents humanity's continuous quest for knowledge, serving as a beacon of progress and unity.

Crafted from the divine essence seized by Prometheus, the vessel underscores the fire's role in advancing communal well-being over individual glory. It evokes memories of the first hearth fires, around which communities formed, cultures flourished, and the bonds of society were forged. This flame was the nucleus of early civilization, where stories were shared, and knowledge was passed down through generations.

The light of the Promethean fire symbolizes the pursuit of understanding, guiding humanity through darkness towards discovery. It is a reminder of Prometheus' sacrifice for human advancement and the ongoing journey of exploration and creativity that defines our species. In its gentle warmth, the ancients found the spark of curiosity that fueled their desire to learn and grow, making the Promethean fire not just a physical beacon, but a metaphorical one, illuminating the path of human progress.
The Promethean fire is a magical fire contained in a finely crafted vessel. The Promethean fire has the following properties:

entries.name: Eternal Warmth
entries: The Promethean fire can't be extinguished by any means. The fire sheds {@quickref Vision and Light||2||bright light} in a 60-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light||2||dim light} for an additional 60 feet, and is able to ignite any fire source without requiring fuel.

entries.name: Beacon of Courage
entries: As an action, a creature holding the Promethean fire's vessel can use its powers to embolden its allies. For the next 8 hours, each creature of the bearer's choice within 60 feet of the fire gains advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}. Once used, this ability can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Artisan's Inspiration
entries: When crafting or repairing items within the light of the Promethean Fire, a creature gains advantage on all checks related to the crafting or repairing process, reflecting the fire's inspiration and guidance in human endeavors.

entries.name: Purifier of Life
entries: By placing a bowl of food or water near the flame for 1 minute, the fire purifies it, rendering it free from of poison and disease. This purification process represents the Promethean fire's nurturing aspect and its role in sustaining life.

item.name: Apollo's Arrow
entries: Apollo's arrows are enhanced by the divine aura of Apollo, the Olympian god of archery, offering unmatched precision and lethality. This exquisite arrow, forged from celestial bronze and adorned with feathers from the sacred swans of Apollo's chariot, shimmers with a divine glow.

You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magical arrow. The Apollo's arrow has the following magical properties. Once it hits a target, the arrow is no longer magical until the next dawn, after which it regains its powers.

entries.name: Guided Strike
entries: An Apollo's arrow seeks its target with unerring accuracy. When you make an attack roll with this arrow, you can invoke the guidance of Apollo to declare that the arrow will automatically hit your target without rolling the attack. When thrown in this way, the Apollo's arrow ignores any benefit provided to the target by being in cover (excluding total cover) or holding a shield. On a hit, the arrow deals an additional {@damage 2d8} radiant damage in addition to the normal weapon's damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be outlined by divine light until the start of your next turn. An affected creature sheds {@quickref Vision and Light||2||bright light} in 30-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light||2||dim light} for an additional 30 feet and is unable to benefit from spells or effects that would turn it {@condition invisible}. Any attack roll made against a creature radiating this divine light has advantage, provided the attacker can see the target.

entries.name: Indestructibility
entries: Reflecting its divine origin and craftsmanship, an Apollo's arrow is indestructible and can't be broken by any means. After it is used, the arrow immediately reappears in the quiver of the creature who threw it.

item.name: Pelt of the Nemean Lion
entries: The Pelt of the Nemean Lion stands as one of the most iconic relics in Greek mythology, embodying the essence of an indomitable beast that once roamed the valley of Nemea. This lion was no ordinary creature; its golden fur was said to be impervious to the edge of any blade or the point of any arrow, making it a symbol of ultimate resilience and strength. The Nemean Lion's fearsome reputation spread far and wide, casting a shadow of dread over the land until it met its match in Heracles (also known as Hercules), the son of Zeus.

The confrontation with the Nemean Lion was the first of Heracles' twelve labors, a series of seemingly impossible tasks set forth by King Eurystheus as a means of testing the hero's strength, cunning, and courage. Heracles' victory over the lion using his immense strength and divine wit - strangling it with his bare hands after realizing its hide was impenetrable - marked the beginning of his legendary journey and solidified his status as one of the greatest heroes in Greek mythology.

After slaying the lion, Heracles skinned the creature using its own claws and donned its pelt as armor. From that moment, the Pelt of the Nemean Lion became as much a part of Heracles' identity as his club or his divine lineage. It served not only as protection in his subsequent labors and battles but also as a powerful symbol of his triumph over the impossible, a testament to the hero's indomitable spirit and the favor of the Olympian gods.

The pelt gleams with a subtle golden light, its fur as impenetrable as ever, and serves as a profound emblem of courage and the enduring power of those who dare to face the impossible. Crafted into a magnificent cloak or armor, the Pelt of the Nemean
Lion is a relic of myth, imbuing its wearer with a fraction of the legendary strength and the invincibility of Heracles.
While attuned to the Pelt of the Nemean Lion, a creature has the following benefits:

entries.name: Legendary Resilience
entries: While wearing the pelt, you gain a +1 bonus to AC and resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, a reflection of the Nemean Lion's own invulnerability.

entries.name: Fearsome Presence
entries: The pelt imbues you with an intimidatory aura, granting you advantage on all Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks and allowing you to add your Strength score modifier to any {@skill Intimidation} check your make. As an action while wearing the pelt, you can attempt to intimidate a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw contested by your Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check or be {@condition frightened} for the next minute. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Enhanced Strength
entries: You have advantage on all Strength ability checks and saving throws you make.

item.name: Thyrsus
entries: The Thyrsus, an emblem of divine revelry and natural abundance, holds a place of honor within the pantheon of sacred symbols associated with Dionysus, the god of wine, ecstasy, and regeneration. This staff, traditionally crafted from fennel and entwined with ivy, crowned with a pine cone at its peak, serves as a tangible link to the ancient rites and rituals of the Dionysian cult. The Maenads, also known as Bacchantes, Dionysus' most devout and frenetic worshippers, brandished the Thyrsus as they partook in the Bacchanals - rituals filled with wild dancing, music, and the consumption of wine, which induced states of divine madness and ecstatic fervor.

The Maenads, whose name translates to 'the raving ones', were not only participants in these rites, but also conduits of Dionysus' divine power, embodying the chaotic and untamed forces of nature that the god himself represented. Adorned in skins of animals, they traversed forests and hills, their celebrations a profound expression of liberation from societal constraints, a return to primal freedom under the patronage of Dionysus. The Bacchanals were occasions of significant religious importance, serving as ceremonies of death and rebirth, where the Maenads experienced the dissolution of self and unity with the divine, a cycle reflective of nature's own rhythms.

The Thyrsus symbolizes this connection between the wild, generative forces of the earth and the transcendental ecstasy of divine communion. It was believed that the staff could bring joy and pain, heal and harm, mirroring the dual nature of Dionysus as both benevolent and wrathful. The pine cone atop the Thyrsus, a symbol of fertility and eternal life, further emphasized the staff's role in rites celebrating the endless cycle of death and renewal, the core of Dionysian worship.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this staff. When you hit a creature with an attack made with the Thyrsus, the target takes an additional {@damage 1d6} psychic damage as the overwhelming frenzy and euphoria associated with Dionysian rites cloud its mind, causing disorientation and pain. While attuned to the Thyrsus, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Ivy's Grasp
entries: As an action, you can tap the Thyrsus on the ground to cast the {@spell entangle} spell (save{@dc 13}) without expending a spell slot. Once used, this ability can't be used again until the next dawn. This power echoes the staff's connection to the earth and the wild, unfettered growth it can inspire, similar to the untamed nature of Dionysian festivities.

entries.name: Wine's Bounty
entries: The Thyrsus has 3 charges. You can use an action during your turn to expend a charge and fill a glass or chalice with a modest quantity of vine (up to 3 gallons) by touching it with the staff.

entries.name: Bacchic Fervor
entries: The Thyrsus enhances your ability to inspire and captivate others. You gain advantage on Charisma ({@skill Performance}) and Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks made to influence others through music, dance, or passionate speech, reflecting the infectious joy of Dionysian revelry.

item.name: Palladium
entries: Within Greek mythology, few artifacts hold a place as significant as the Palladium. This revered wooden statue, representing Athena, the goddess of wisdom, was said to be the protector of the city of Troy. Legend holds that as long as the Palladium remained within
Troy's walls, the city would be impervious to invasion and harm.

For this reason, the story of the Palladium intertwines closely with the narratives of heroism and treachery that characterize the Trojan War. It is said that the Palladium's loss marked the beginning of Troy's downfall, a pivotal moment that underscored the artifact's crucial role in the city's fate. The theft of the Palladium was a feat performed by Odysseus and Diomedes, heroes of Greece known for their wit and valor who undertook a perilous mission to infiltrate Troy.

Utilizing a secret passage, they managed to evade the city's defenses and abscond with the Palladium, leaving Troy vulnerable for the first time. This act of desecration not only stripped the city of Athena's protection but also demoralized its inhabitants, setting the stage for the infamous deception of the Trojan Horse. The theft of the Palladium by Odysseus and Diomedes is emblematic of the complex interplay between divine will and human agency that pervades the entirety of Greek mythology. The Palladium is a small statuette of Athena carved out of wood. The Palladium has the following properties:

entries.name: Divine Protection
entries: The presence of the Palladium within a city, settlement, or stronghold imbues its walls and structures with a divine resilience, granting them resistance to all damage types. Additionally, the area is shrouded in a subtle, divine aura that makes scrying and other forms of magical spying more difficult, increasing the DC of similar spells and effects by 5.

entries.name: Wisdom of Athena
entries: While held within a physical location, the Palladium grants insight and clarity to the settlement's sovereign, granting it a +2 bonus to Wisdom and Intelligence scores up to a maximum of 30, representing Athena's blessing of wisdom and strategic acumen.

entries.name: Magical Warding
entries: The entire city protected by the Palladium is permanently subjected to the effects of the {@spell forbiddance} spell, preventing any form of teleportation into it.

entries.name: Curse of Betrayal
entries: Should the Palladium be stolen or removed with ill intent, the thief becomes cursed, becoming plagued by nightmares. While in possession of the Palladium, a cursed creature has disadvantage on all attack rolls and saving throw as long as it keeps the artifact. Only returning the Palladium or a successful appeal to Athena are able to lift the curse.

item.name: Hermes' Winged Sandals
entries: Hermes' winged sandals, known in mythology for their enchanting appearance and remarkable abilities, are central to the tales of Hermes, the fleet-footed messenger who connected the realms of gods and men. These sandals are often depicted as golden and crafted with delicate wings at the heel or ankle, fluttering with each step or flight Hermes took across the skies. This iconic imagery has been celebrated in numerous artworks and literature, symbolizing Hermes' swift and agile nature.

According to the myths, these sandals were endowed with magical properties that allowed Hermes to move with the speed of the wind, making him {@condition invisible} to mortals and immortals alike when he wished. This ability was crucial in carrying out the duties Zeus bestowed upon him, from delivering messages to leading souls to the realm of Hades. The sandals' divine magic facilitated Hermes' many roles, from the god of commerce and communication to the trickster and guide of souls, by granting him the ultimate freedom of movement.

Their portrayal in various stories - from aiding Perseus in his quest to slay Medusa to Hermes' numerous intervention in the lives of gods and mortals alike - underscores Hermes' connection to the human experience, as the sandals were gifts that enabled interactions and the execution of divine will within the human realm.
While attuned to the Hermes' winged sandals, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Legendary Speed
entries: While wearing the sandals, your walking speed increases to 60 feet (unless it is already 60 feet or higher), and you gain a flying speed of 90 feet and the ability to hover.

entries.name: Messenger's Agility
entries: As a bonus action during your turn, you can invoke the power of Hermes to double your speed for 1 minute. Once used, this ability can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Divine Diplomacy
entries: While attuned to the sandals, you gain advantage in (Charisma) {@skill Persuasion} checks and you know if you hear a lie.

entries.name: Master of Stealth
entries: The sandals enhance your natural stealth, granting advantage on (Dexterity) {@skill Stealth} checks. This echoes Hermes' role as the patron of thieves and his legendary cunning and stealth.

entries.name: Guidance of Hermes
entries: Once per day, you can invoke the guidance of Hermes for insight into a specific course of action to take, as if casting the {@spell commune} spell without expending a spell slot or consuming material components.

entries.name: Unbound Freedom
entries: The sandals imbue you with a profound sense of liberation, giving you immunity to being {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition restrained}, knocked {@condition prone}, or pushed against your will.

entries.name: Feathered Descent
entries: You can extend Hermes' mastery over flight to others. As a reaction when you see a creature within 60 feet of your falling, you can choose any number of creatures you can see within 60 feet of you. The targets fall at a rate of 60 feet per round, take no damage from falling, and can always land on their feet, as if under the effect of the {@spell feather fall} spell. Once used, this ability can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Silent Steps
entries: While wearing the sandals, your footsteps or movements make no sound, regardless of the surface you are moving on.

item.name: Girdle of Hippolyta
entries: The Girdle of Hippolyta is deeply rooted in the myths and legends surrounding the Amazon queen, Hippolyta.

This ornate belt was not only a symbol of her authority over the Amazons but also a representation of her strength and her royal lineage. According to legend, Hippolyta's girdle was a gift from her father, Ares, the god of war, which bestowed upon her both protection and the divine right to lead her people.

In the epic tales, the girdle was sought by Heracles as one of his twelve labors. Heracles was tasked with retrieving it as a token of his bravery and skill, a mission that would bring him to the shores of the land ruled by the warrior women and lead to encounters marked by both diplomacy and conflict.
While attuned to the Girdle of Hippolyta, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Charismatic Authority
entries: While wearing the Girdle of Hippolyta, you gain advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) and Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks.

entries.name: Commanding Presence
entries: As an action during your turn, you can invoke the natural leadership qualities bestowed by the belt to cast the {@spell command} spell (save{@dc 15}) without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. Once used, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Warrior's Resolve
entries: While wearing the belt, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, representing the legendary courage and unwavering resolve of Hippolyta.

item.name: Head of Medusa
entries: The Head of Medusa is one of the most formidable artifacts described across Greek myths, encapsulating the tragic and fearsome legacy of its former owner, Medusa. Once a beautiful and devout priestess of Athena, Medusa was transformed into a Gorgon as a divine punishment - her lustrous hair turned into venomous serpents and her once comforting gaze became a horrific weapon that turned onlookers into stone. This curse made Medusa a symbol of ultimate dread, an unwilling monster shunned and feared by all.

Medusa lived in isolation, her gaze a lethal threat to any who crossed her path, until her fateful encounter with Perseus. Commissioned by King Polydectes to bring back Medusa's head, Perseus embarked on his quest armed with gifts from the gods, including a reflective shield from Athena, winged sandals from Hermes, and a sword created by Hephaestus himself. Using the shield to view Medusa indirectly, Perseus was able to behead her without turning to stone, thereafter using her head as a powerful weapon.

In the aftermath of their encounter, the head of Medusa retained its petrifying powers. Perseus used it to defeat his enemies and achieve heroic feats, such as rescuing Andromeda and overthrowing tyrants who had wronged him. After his adventures, he gifted the head to Athena, who mounted it on her shield, the Aegis, as a potent symbol of protection and terror, imbuing the shield with the ability to ward off evil.
The Head of Medusa has the following properties:

entries.name: Petrifying Gaze
entries: As an bonus action while holding the Head of Medusa, you can direct its gaze in a 60-foot cone originating from it. Each creature starting its turn within the area or entering it for the first time in a turn must succeed on a{@dc 23} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition restrained} as its flesh begins to harden.

A creature {@condition restrained} by the Head of Medusa must repeat the Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a {@condition restrained} creature fails the saving throw for two times on subsequent turns, its flesh continues to harden, imposing it disadvantage on all saving throws until the {@condition restrained} condition ends. After failing a third save in a row, a creature is turned to stone and subjected to the {@condition petrified} condition until freed by a {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: Serpentine Whispers
entries: The Head of Medusa occasionally whispers secrets or warning to its bearer, granting it advantage on initiative rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks.

item.name: Bow of Heracles
entries: The Bow of Heracles, crafted from the horns of a mighty beast and strung with unbreakable golden threads, is a legendary weapon synonymous with Herculean strength and precision. This formidable bow was one of Heracles' primary weapons, used throughout his numerous labors and heroic deeds, demonstrating his prowess not only in strength but also in archery. Born to Zeus and the mortal Alcmene, Heracles was gifted with superhuman strength and destined for a life marked by both great deeds and grave trials. His most famous challenges, the Twelve Labors, were penances for the grievous act of slaying his own family, a tragedy inflicted upon him by the goddess Hera's wrath. After his death and subsequent ascension to godhood, Heracles' weapons, including his bow, were venerated as symbols of his enduring legacy - icons of the capacity to overcome adversity through strength and resilience.
Unlike ordinary bows, which rely on the dexterity of the wielder, the Bow of Heracles harnesses the user's brute strength to propel arrows with devastating force.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this longbow. The Bow of Heracles has the following properties:

entries.name: Herculean Draw
entries: The Bow of Heracles allows you to use your Strength modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier for attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, representing its need for immense physical strength to draw fully.

entries.name: Mighty Range
entries: The Bow of Heracles has a normal range of 200 feet and a long range of 800 feet, allowing you to hit targets from great distances as Heracles did when he faced foes across vast battlefields.

entries.name: Piercing Shot
entries: When you make an attack with this bow, you can declare it will be a Piercing Shot. The arrow loosed will fly with such force that it can pierce through multiple enemies. Instead of making an attack roll, you can force all creatures in a 100-foot line that is 5 feet wide to make a{@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 6d8} piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. Once used, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Quiver of the Hunter
entries: The Bow of Heracles magically produces a nonmagical arrow each time you draw the bowstring, ensuring that you never run out of ammunition.

entries.name: Heroic Resilience
entries: While attuned to the Bow of Heracles, you gain resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}, reflecting Heracles' resilience during his famed encounter with the venomous Hydra.

item.name: Golden Apple of the Hesperides
entries: The Golden Apples of the Hesperides are fabled fruits from ancient Greek mythology, grown in a divine garden guarded by the Hesperides, nymphs of the evening and daughters of Atlas. These apples were not only sought after for their beauty but also for their magical properties, as they were believed to grant immortality to whoever consumed them. The garden was also protected by Ladon, a fearsome dragon, making the task of obtaining these apples one of the celebrated Twelve Labors of Heracles.

The apples radiate a soft, golden glow and emit a sweet, enchanting aroma that can refresh the spirit and heal the body. They are associated with the divine, representing a source of life and rejuvenation, coveted by gods and mortals alike. While in possession of one or more Golden Apples, a creature emanates an aura that grants it advantage on all Charisma checks made to interact with fey and celestial creatures, mirroring the enchanting nature of the apples. As an action, a creature holding a Golden Apple of the Hesperides can eat it, gaining the following benefits:

entries.name: Eternal Vigor
entries: Consuming one of the Golden Apples grants the eater the benefits of a {@spell greater restoration} spell.

entries.name: Renewal of Youth
entries: Upon consuming the apple, the eater's physical age is reduced by 1 year, to a minimum of 13 years. A creature that benefits from this effect is immune to have its age reduced by eating a Golden Apple of the Hesperides for the next month.

entries.name: Elixir of Health
entries: In addition to its restorative powers, eating the apple provides the consumer with an increase in vitality. For the next 24 hours, the creature gains 20 temporary hit points and advantage on Constitution saving throws, reflecting the apple's strengthening qualities.

entries.name: Rare Delight
entries: The apple's enchanting flavor and divine origin grant inspiration once consumed. For the next 24 hours, the consumer can choose to add a {@dice d10} to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, declaring it after seeing the roll but before knowing the result.

item.name: Pandora's Box
entries: Pandora's Box is one of the most iconic and enigmatic artifacts in Greek mythology, rich with layers of meaning and symbolism. According to legend, Pandora was the first woman created by the gods, fashioned by Hephaestus from clay as part of the divine plan of Zeus.
Each god contributed something to perfect her: Athena clothed her, Aphrodite gave her beauty, and Hermes bestowed upon her cunning and bold curiosity.

Zeus presented Pandora to Epimetheus, a Titan whose name means 'afterthought', as a gift. However, along with Pandora, Zeus gave another gift - a beautifully crafted box, which was, in fact, an intricately decorated jar (or 'pithos'). Zeus instructed Pandora never to open this container. It was said to hold special gifts from the gods, but in truth, it contained all the evils that could plague mankind, including illness, despair, malice, greed, old age, deceit, and strife - punishments for humankind's reception of the stolen gift of fire from Prometheus.

Despite the warning, Pandora's curiosity, a trait bestowed upon her by the very gods, eventually overwhelmed her resolve. One day, unable to resist temptation any longer, she lifted the lid of the box. Immediately, all the evils it contained burst out, spreading over the earth to a􀃧ict human beings forever. Yet, all was not lost. As Pandora quickly closed the box, one last thing remained inside - Hope. This small spirit alone had not escaped, and when Pandora later opened the box again, Hope emerged to provide a counterbalance to the sufferings unleashed upon the world.

The tale of Pandora is often considered a story of unintended consequences, illustrating the unexpected outcomes that can arise from seemingly innocent actions. The box itself, often depicted as a modest yet ornate vessel, holds a mysterious allure, symbolizing the dual potential for unleashing challenges and offering the means to overcome them.
Pandora's Box is an intricately ornated box with the following properties:

entries.name: Guardian of Miseries
entries: As long as Pandora's box remains closed, a creature attuned to it gains a +3 bonus to AC and saving throws, symbolizing the protective influence of foresight and self-control.

entries.name: Release of Evils
entries: As an action, a creature holding Pandora's Box can slightly open it, allowing spectral forms of minor evils to escape. All creatures within 30 feet of the box must succeed on a{@dc 23} Wisdom saving throw or be affected by a random condition for the next minute. The condition is determined by rolling a {@dice d10} and consulting the result with the following table.

entries.caption: Pandora's Box Release of Evils Table

entries.name: Apocalyptic Release
entries: As an action, a creature holding Pandora's box can completely open it, triggering a catastrophic release of major evils upon the world. This event causes widespread calamity, such as pandemics, natural disasters, and war, affecting the entire world.
After this event, the box automatically closes itself and can't be opened again for a century.

entries.name: Curse of Curiosity
entries: A creature attuned to Pandora's Box struggles with overwhelming curiosity. The creature must succeed on a{@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw each morning or feel compelled to open it, triggering a cataclysm as detailed in the Apocalyptic Release feature.

entries.name: Inexorable Revelation
entries: Once per year, the bearer can use an action to consult the box for divine insight into a significant mystery or a future event by tapping into the deep, forbidden knowledge contained within it.

item.name: Dragon's Teeth Satchel
entries: This rugged satchel, crafted from the hide of a mythical dragon, contains a set of enchanted dragon's teeth akin to those used by Cadmus in the ancient myth of Thebes' founding. Legend has it that Cadmus, having slain a sacred dragon of Ares, sowed its teeth into the earth as instructed by Athena. From these teeth sprang fierce Spartoi warriors, fully armed and ready to aid Cadmus in establishing the city of Thebes. With spears in hand and shields adorned, the Spartoi were fierce and loyal, destined to play the roles of guardians in the fabled history of Thebes.

Inside the satchel are {@dice 1d4 + 1} dragon's teeth. As an action while holding the satchel, you can scatter one tooth onto the ground and speak the command words etched into the satchel. When you do so, a {@creature spartoi warrior|MythologicalCreatures} rises from the ground, obeying your commands and acting on your initiative.
The summoned creature remain for 1 hour before returning to the earth. Once all teeth have been used, the satchel loses its magic.

item.name: Ruyi Jingu Bang
item.reqAttune: by a creature of chaotic alignment
entries: Ruyi Jingu Bang is the legendary staff bound to the fate of Sun Wukong, the Monkey King. Selected by Sun Wukong from the arsenal of the Dragon King of the Eastern Sea, the Ruyi Jingu Bang was no ordinary weapon. It possessed the ability to change its size at its master's whim, from no larger than a needle to tall enough to pierce the clouds. This ability not only showcased the staff's intrinsic magic but also mirrored Sun Wukong's own transformative nature, his defiance of the limits imposed by the heavens, and his journey from a stone born of primal chaos to a deity. The staff's name, meaning 'As-You-Will Gold-Banded Cudgel', signifies the fluidity and adaptability of its form and the will of its wielder to challenge the might of the cosmos and the rigid order of the celestial bureaucracy.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this staff. The staff has the following properties:

entries.name: Growth
entries: As a bonus action, you can command the staff to grow, increasing its reach to 30 feet and its damage to {@dice 2d10}. This effect can be dismissed as a bonus action.

entries.name: Sweeping Strike
entries: Once per short rest, when the staff is in its grown state, you can make a special sweeping attack with it. You sweep the area in front of you, targeting all creatures in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the cone must make a{@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 6d10} bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and not be knocked {@condition prone} on a successful one.

entries.name: Charges
entries: The staff has 5 charges that can be expended to use its poweful abilities. The staff regains {@dice 1d4 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn.

entries.name: Legendary Strike
entries: When you hit with an attack using this staff, you can expend two charges to deal an additional {@damage 6d10} radiant damage, and the target must make a{@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Mythical Transformation
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend a charge to invoke the staff's mythical power, transforming it into its true divine form for 1 minute.
While in this form, the staff deals an additional {@damage 1d10} radiant damage on a hit.

entries.name: Summon Ruyi Jingu Bang Copy
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend one charge to summon a copy of the Ruyi Jingu Bang at a location within 30 feet of you, immediately making an attack with it. As a bonus action on subsequent turns, you can move the copy up to 30 feet and make an attack with it. The copy duplicates the damage and effects of your attacks made with the Ruyi Jingu Bang.

foundryEffects.name: Ruyi Jingu Bang Mythical Transformation Damage

item.name: Green Dragon Crescent Blade
entries: The Green Dragon Crescent Blade, known as 'Frost Fair

Blade' (legend says how during a battle in the snow, the blade had so much blood on it, causing it to freeze and make a layer of frost on the blade), is a legendary glaive that once carved its name across the annals of history, wielded by the valorous general Guan Yu in the era of the Three Kingdoms. Its blade, emerald-green and shimmering like the scales of a dragon, reflects the light of the sun and moon, casting a glow that seems to pierce the very soul of darkness. The weapon is adorned with intricate carvings, signifying the balance of power and grace. The wielder of this blade is said to command the respect of both the heavens and the earth, embodying the virtues of honor and courage that transcend mortal boundaries.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this glaive. The Green Dragon Crescent Blade has the following properties:

entries.name: Dragon's Might
entries: As a bonus action, you can infuse the glaive with energy, causing it to exude a powerful aura.

For the next minute, any creature hit by the blade takes an additional {@damage 1d10} force damage, and the ground within 5 feet of where you struck becomes {@quickref difficult terrain||3} for every creature other than you until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Celestial Wind
entries: Once per short rest, you can swing the blade to release a gust of divine wind in a 60-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a{@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 4d10} slashing damage plus {@damage 4d10} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. This wind extinguishes all non-magical flames in its path and disperses fog, smoke, and other gases.

entries.name: Unyielding Resolve
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can choose to drop to 1 hit point instead. You can use this feature once per long rest. Additionally, when this feature is used, your attacks with the Green Dragon Crescent Blade deal maximum damage until the end of your next turn.

foundryEffects.name: Green Dragon Crescent Blade Dragon's Might Damage

item.name: Parashu
entries: Parashu, the divine axe bestowed by Lord Shiva to Parashuram, resonates with the echoes of ancient penance, wrath, and righteousness. This weapon, a celestial artifact, was not merely a tool of warfare but a symbol of the balance between the serene wisdom of a Brahmin and the fierce courage of a Kshatriya. Crafted in the heavenly anvils of Mount Kailash, its blade is etched with sacred mantras, radiating a divine luminescence capable of dispelling darkness both physical and spiritual.

The lore of Parashu is interwoven with the legend of its wielder, Parashuram, the sixth avatar of Lord Vishnu, born to Sage Jamadagni and Renuka. Parashuram, a Brahmin with the heart of a warrior, embodied the virtues of both castes, earning him his divine weapon as a testament to his unwavering dedication and austerity. Shiva, impressed by Parashuram's discipline and devotion, gifted him Parashu, which would become an extension of his will to uphold dharma.

Throughout its existence, Parashu has been a witness and participant in countless battles, shaping the course of history and the fate of dynasties. Its blade has tasted the blood of warriors and tyrants, forever altering the landscapes of both the physical and astral realms.

Parashuram's vow to rid the earth of unjust Kshatriyas saw the axe's blade unleashed in righteous fury, decimating the warrior class twenty-one times over, a cycle of vengeance that would stain the earth and the weapon with the blood of countless souls.
Yet, the axe is not merely an instrument of destruction.

Parashuram, with Parashu in hand, carved out new lands from the sea, demonstrating its ability to create and nurture as much as to annihilate. This duality mirrors the complex nature of its master: destroyer and protector, warrior and sage.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this battleaxe. Parashu has the following properties:

entries.name: Celestial Strike
entries: When you hit with an attack using Parashu, you deal an extra {@damage 2d10} radiant damage to the target.

entries.name: Divine Command
entries: As a bonus action, you can command Parashu to emit a dazzling light, illuminating brightly in a 60-foot radius and radiating {@quickref Vision and Light||2||dim light} for an additional 60 feet. Enemies within the light's radius have disadvantage on attack rolls against you. This effect lasts for 1 minute and can be used once per long rest.

entries.name: Earth Sculptor
entries: Parashu holds the power to alter landscapes. You can touch the ground with Parashu and cast the {@spell move earth} spell without expending a spell slot or needing material components.

entries.name: Purge of Evil
entries: You can cast the {@spell dispel evil and good} spell without expending a spell slot or needing material components.

entries.name: Redemption
entries: Once per week, as an action, you can cast the {@spell true resurrection} spell without expending a spell slot or needing material components.

entries.name: Wrath of the Righteous
entries: Once per short rest, you can invoke the power of Parashu to unleash a wave of divine energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a{@dc 23} Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 15d10} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Curse of Bloodshed
entries: The legacy of violence that Parashu carries cannot be easily forgotten. After significant battles where more than ten creatures are killed, the wielder may feel the weight of the lives taken, a reminder of the cycle of vengeance and the importance of seeking peace and justice over endless conflict. The wielder must succeed on a{@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or gain a level of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: Parashu is a sentient lawful neutral weapon with an Intelligence of 18, a Wisdom of 20, and a Charisma of 24. It has hearing and {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 120 feet. The weapon can communicate with its wielder telepathically and can speak, read, and understand Common, Sanskrit, and Celestial. Parashu's purpose is to eradicate evil, enforce justice, and guide its wielder on the path of righteousness, much like its original master, Parashuram.

item.name: Spatial Ring (Uncommon)
entries: The Spatial Ring, a marvel of magical craftsmanship, links the physical realm to an extradimensional space, creating a pocket dimension accessible only to its wearer. This ring is a staple in the arsenal of Immortal Cultivators, wizards, and adventurers across myriad worlds of Asian fantasy, from the ethereal realms of Chinese Wuxia, Xianxia, and Xuanhuan to the enchanted landscapes of Japanese magic fantasy. Crafted with mastery over Spatial law or infused with potent spatial magic, the Spatial Ring serves as a portable vault, a secret chamber that one can carry on their finger.
A user wearing it can summon items within the ring's space within 5 feet of it with a mere thought or store them in by touching them. Summoning or storing one item can be done as a free action.

entries.name: Extradimensional Space
entries: The space inside forms a cube with a volume of 6 cubic feet.

entries.name: Imprinting a Spiritual Mark
entries: The marking process involves a 10-minute ritual where the user must focus on the ring, forging a connection between their soul and the ring. This process make it impossible for others to use this ring without erasing the spiritual mark first.

entries.name: Erasing a Spiritual Mark
entries: To erase an existing spiritual mark and claim the ring as their own, a new user must also perform a 10-minute ritual and succeed on a Wisdom check with the difficulty based on the ring's rarity:{@dc 13} for uncommon,{@dc 15} for rare,{@dc 18} for very rare, and{@dc 21} for legendary. A failed attempt prevents the creature from trying again for 24 hours, as their soul requires rest. They can attempt the ritual again before this period, by taking a level of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Spatial Distortion
entries: If the Spatial Ring is overloaded, or exposed to an effect that disrupts spatial magic, it ruptures and is destroyed, and its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. Similarly, placing the Spatial Ring within another extradimensional space such as a {@item Bag of Holding}, {@item Portable Hole}, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane, with the aforementioned consequences.
